# Calculating pi
We place a circle with radius 1 and a square with radius 1, with side 2, at the starting point of the coordinate system.
<img src="data:image/.png;base64," 
alt="circle picture" />


The area of the circle is $ \ pi r ^ 2 $, ie $ \ pi $, and the area of the square is $ a ^ 2 $, ie $ 4 $. The fraction of the square covered by the circle is $ \ pi / 4 $.

Let us choose two random coordinates inside the square, that is, two random numbers between -1 and 1. The probability that this point also lies inside the circle is equal to $ \ pi / 4 $.

We repeat this a thousand times. Inside the circle will lie about $ n = 1000 \ times \ pi / 4 $ points. If we didnâ€™t know how much $ pi $ is, we could actually do this experiment; with that we would get the upper $ n $, and from this $ n $ we can, if we turn the formula around, calculate the value of $ \ pi $.

## Mandatory task
Write a program that draws 1000 random coordinates inside a square, (silently) counts how many are inside a circle, and finally displays the $ \ pi $ calculated in this way.

This will help you: if you type from random import * at the beginning of the program, the random () function will appear, returning a random number between 0 and 1. How to change this to numbers between -1 and 1, figure out for yourself. You also tackle math on your own.

## Additional task
Modify the program by adding 1000 new random selections. And another 1000. And another 1000. And another 1000. And another ... Do that until it happens that when some new 1000 attempts are added, $ \ pi $ changes by less than 0.000001.

## Purely extra task (doesn't count anywhere)
Those who are bored with the above tasks can calculate $ \ pi $ by simulating a Buffon needle. To make it easier, the needle should be as wide as the stripes on the ground, so that $ p = 2 / \ pi $ holds.
